text:
From DMs

Using Metatheory.jl with Mixtape.jl won't be a big challenge, for each transform, it will be a matter of adding each IR statement to an e-graph, remembering which variable corresponds to each equivalence class, using this information to add the arguments of the other statements as existing equivalence classes. After executing equality saturation, it will be slightly harder to generate a new IR from the optimized e-graph, but not a huge challenge

text: <@U01K2JB9GPJ> what happens after eq saturation? Do we now know what statements have been “merged”?

elements.text: what happens after eq saturation? Do we now know what statements have been “merged”?

text: I haven't yet added the "merge" history but yes. It will be trivial to implement it and we will know which statements were merged easily.

elements.text: I haven't yet added the "merge" history but yes. It will be trivial to implement it and we will know which statements were merged easily.

text: I’m forgetting why operating on typed IR is useful to MT

elements.text: I’m forgetting why operating on typed IR is useful to MT

text: We chatted with <@U674T3KB3> about potential composable (semantic-preserving possibly?) compiler transforms and optimization passes based on MT algebraic rules. Using typed IR would allow for type-dependent rules (e.g `x-x => 0` does not always hold for matrices but does hold for numbers). There's surely more "whys", but keno knows them better than me.

elements.text: about potential composable (semantic-preserving possibly?) compiler transforms and optimization passes based on MT algebraic rules. Using typed IR would allow for type-dependent rules (e.g
does not always hold for matrices but does hold for numbers). There's surely more "whys", but keno knows them better than me.

text: Ah interesting. Is there any interesting stuff to work on untyped IR? I suspect that (for the most part) a lot of the real interesting stuff will happen later, but I’d be curious to understand how I could support any experiments you’re interested in doing now.
